editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Thompson Family Charitable Trust

msDesc.head: Anselm of Laon, gloss on Matthew

msItem.incipit: Sancti spiritus adsit nobis gratia Cum post ascensionem domini spiritus sanctus corda discipulorum illustrasset
msItem.explicit: purgati cristo ad quem tendimur coniungamur et ei adhabeamus
msItem.author: ANSELM OF LAON
msItem.title: the prologue to the Glossae in Matthaeum
msItem.note: (Stegmüller, RB 1359 [2:114], identifying the following text as such), copied by the glossing hand.

msItem.incipit: Mathevs ex iudea sicut in ordine primus ponitur ita euangelium [fol. 5rc, the gloss begins] Cum multi scripsisse euangelia legantur soli iiiior. euangeliste [fol. 7rb, the gloss begins] Matheus cum primo predicasset in iudea uolens transire ad gentes [the text begins] L [an unfilled decorative incipit] braham fides genuit prima generacio ysaac secunda generacio Ysaac autem genuit iacob
msItem.explicit: [fol. 111va, the gloss ends] non sunt de futuri qui mansione [m. q. marked for reversal] diuina sunt digni Eplicjt [sic] hoc opvs [the text ends] Et ecce ego uobiscum diuinitate sum omnibus diebus confinitis laboribus mecum regnabitis usque ad consumacionem seculi
msItem.title: Matthew, with a pre-ANSELMian set of glosses associable with Laon
msItem.note: see the discussions: Heinrich Weisweiler, ‘Paschasius Radbertus als Vermittler…’, Scholastik 35 (1960), 363–402, 503–36; and Beryl Smalley, ‘Some Gospel Commentaries of the Early Twelfth Century’, Recherches de théologie ancienne et médiévale 45 (1978), 147–80 (our MS treated at 162–5). The prologue ends on fol. 6, and fol. 6v is blank.

msItem.incipit: Suggillo a suggo tractum a lamijs id est trangulo Secularis sapiencia quasi coluber per humum serpit
msItem.explicit: illo donante dicitur qui est ueritas Basan confusio dicitur’
msItem.title: Theological notes
msItem.note: mainly etymological, in the hand of the gloss, ed. Smalley 163–4. The remainder of the leaf was originally blank.

msItem.incipit: Salue mater saluatoris uas electum uas honoris uas celestis gratie
msItem.explicit: salua gratis et nos tue claritatis configura gloria amen
msItem.author: ADAM OF ST VICTOR
msItem.title: Hymn
msItem.note: in Ulysse Chevalier, Repertorium Hymnologicum, 2 vols. (Louvain, 1892–7), no. 18051. With musical notation, s. xiii in.; at the page foot, an added line of music with the stanza ‘Ebur candens castitatis aurum fuluum caritatis presignans misteria’. On fol. iv, further pen-trials, including copies of bits of the hymn.

collation.formula: 18 (–5, –6, –7, –8, the first three of them stubs) 2–138 142.
collation.signatures: quires signed with a roman numeral, either on the first recto (quires 3–10) or the last verso (quires 11–13). In this system, quires 3–13 = ii–xii.
A leaf signature ‘c’ may appear on fol. 71.

layoutDesc.layout:
Fols. 1–4v in double columns, each column
195 53 , with 11–12 mm between columns, in 44 lines to the column.

The remainder in text and gloss format: a central column of 165 50 in 16 lines, flanked by two gloss columns, 50 mm (the leading edge) and 20 mm (the gutter) wide—in its full extent 50 lines and
195–200 mm high. Prickings; bounded and ruled in brown crayon (the gloss ruled only as needed, with some pages very nearly blank).

handDesc.handNote: Written in two sizes of protogothic book-hand. Punctuation by point only.

decoDesc.decoNote: Generally unadorned. A 2-line red arabesque capital on fol. 5; a 7-line red and brown capital on fol. 7 (with the decorated opening for the text left incomplete).
Occasional 1-line red arabesque capitals at chapter breaks and to separate the patriarchs in ch. 1.
Large in-text capitals to divide the verses, with no notation of chapters.
Rough sketches of the crucifixion in pencil on fols. 19v and 107v.
See AT, no. 90 (12), calling the MS French, s. xii2/4, the drawings English, s. xii3/4, and plate vi (fol. 19v).

binding.p: A modern replacement. Sewn on five thongs. At the front, a marbled paper leaf and two modern paper flyleaves; at the rear, one medieval vellum flyleaf (probably an old pastedown), mounted on paper, one modern paper flyleaf, and another marbled leaf (iv–vi).

history.provenance: Pen-trials and notes (fol. 112ra, ss. xiii in., xiii ex., s. xv).

‘hic est liber sanctorum de May [the Isle of May, Fife] quem qui celauerit uel fraudem de eo fecerit anathema sit’ (mounted on a vellum tag, fol. iiiv; s. xii ex.) (Ker, MLGB 130), the sole surviving book from this house.
‘William Laud’ (fol. 1, upper margin; above a cancelled inscription).
history.acquisition: ‘Liber Collegij Sanctj Johannis Baptistae Oxon’ ex dono venerabilis virj Guilielmi Laud Doctoris Thaeologiae ejusdem Collegii Praesidis’ (fol. 2, upper margin).

source.bibl: Ralph Hanna, A descriptive catalogue of the western medieval manuscripts of St. John's College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact St John's College Library.

listBibl.bibl: J. J. G. Alexander and Elźbieta Temple, Illuminated Manuscripts in Oxford College Libraries, the University Archives and the Taylor Institution (Oxford, 1985).

N. R. Ker, Medieval Libraries of Great Britain: A List of Surviving Books. Royal Historical Society Guides and Handbooks. 2nd edn. (London, 1964), extended by Andrew G. Watson, MLGB: Supplement to the Second Edition. RHS Guides and Handbooks 15 (1987).
Beryl Smalley, ‘Some Gospel Commentaries of the Early Twelfth Century’, Recherches de théologie ancienne et médiévale 45 (1978), 147–80.
Friederich Stegmüller, Repertorium Biblicum Medii Aevi, 11 vols. (Madrid, 1950–80).
Heinrich Weisweiler, ‘Paschasius Radbertus als Vermittler…’, Scholastik 35 (1960), 363–402, 503–36
